posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
For folks experimenting with GTSAM for pose estimation:

I contributed some factors to the project, and I’d like your feedback.

One of them, “PlanarProjectionFactor1,” estimates Pose2d given constant landmarks, camera calibration and offset.  The use case here is “smoothing,” e.g. using one of the Fixed Lag Smoother classes.  Another, “PlanarProjectionFactor3,” uses constant landmarks to estimate pose, calibration, and offset simultaneously – the use case here is automatic camera calibration.  There’s also an SFM factor, but since our landmarks are fixed, it’s not as useful.

Anyway, I’d like these to be generally useful to FRC , so please comment on this PR!

projection and SFM for 2d poses borglab:develop ← truher:team100_frc_factors opened 12:34AM - 16 Dec 24 UTC truher +784 -0

opened 12:34AM - 16 Dec 24 UTC truher +784 -0

opened 12:34AM - 16 Dec 24 UTC

truher

+784 -0

These are the "robot on the floor" versions of SFM and Projection factors, patte … rned after the similarly-named pose3 versions.  These are intended for localization in high school robotics, where the landmarks are AprilTag markers in known locations.

PlanarProjectionFactor uses constant Pose3 landmarks, a constant camera Pose3 offset, and a constant camera Cal3DS2 calibration.  The measurement is camera pixels.  The free variable is a Pose2 representing the position of the robot on the floor, and the expectation is that this factor will be used for real-time smoothing.

PlanarSFMFactor uses the same robot Pose2 variable, constant Pose3 landmarks and camera pixel measurement, as above, but instead of using constant camera Pose3 offset and Cal3DS2 calibration, these are also variables.  This factor is primarily intended for calibration of camera offset and distortion.

Oh, one important thing, the "zero" camera offset is such that the camera bore is parallel to the "zero" pose2 (i.e. facing +x), which I think may be different than the normal body-offset zero.  Using the same zero as the pose2 seems less confusing to clients (who expect a zero offset camera to be looking at pose2 zero), but it might be more confusing to folks who are more familiar with the gtsam camera.

Using the same zero as the pose2 seems less confusing to clients (who expect a zero offset camera to be looking at pose2 zero), but it might be more confusing to folks who are more familiar with the gtsam camera.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
GTSAM implements the “Factor Graph” approach to estimation.  The general idea is to decompose the global estimation problem into a number of local terms (“factors”) representing residuals (e.g. camera re-projection error), and then iteratively solve the resulting (sparse) nonlinear system.  If the errors are Gaussian, then this is a maximum-likelihood estimator.

A nice property of this estimator is that it optimizes over the factor residuals in measurement space, e.g. camera pixels.  (Today we specify a pose-isotropic uncertainty of the camera-derived pose estimate, which is definitely wrong.)

By Frank Dellaert, @fdellaert on Twitter

GTSAM is a BSD-licensed C++ library that implements sensor fusion for robotics and computer vision using factor graphs.

GTSAM includes many factors useful in the robotics domain, e.g. representing odometry, or the bearing to a target, etc, and also variable types like 2d and 3d poses, cameras with distortion, etc.  Much of this system is aimed at more-difficult problems than we encounter in FRC , e.g. airborne SLAM.  The system is written in C++ with Matlab and python wrappers: we use python on Raspberry Pi.

GitHub - borglab/gtsam: GTSAM is a library of C++ classes that implement... GTSAM is a library of C++ classes that implement smoothing and mapping (SAM) in robotics and vision, using factor graphs and Bayes networks as the underlying computing paradigm rather than sparse matrices.

GTSAM is a library of C++ classes that implement smoothing and mapping (SAM) in robotics and vision, using factor graphs and Bayes networks as the underlying computing paradigm rather than sparse matrices.

The specific thing I made is a factor that represents the camera residual for 2d poses but 3d targets, which happened not to have been written before.

posts.name: Matthew Milunic
posts.cooked: Thank you so much for making this! I’ve been looking into GTSAM, and so far it seems pretty cool. I managed to make a factor for Swerve/Mechanum/Tank odometry + Slip Estimation along with a Gyro factor, but I have no idea how like cameras and their different calibration matrixes work, so thanks for this massive contribution! As soon as I get it a little more polished I plan on posting on CD .

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
sounds good.  I’m curious how you implemented the slip estimator.  it would be cool to have a real tire model in there.

You can read our design doc 1 for more about how our thing works, though the doc doesn’t entirely match reality.   Our code 2 might also be helpful, it implements both the localizer and the calibrator.  There are tests nearby that exercise the whole thing.

We didn’t actually use any of this during the comp season this year.  We came up with better ways to do distortion calibration and offset calibration, and improved our camera hardware, and now our pose estimates are really good, despite the simplistic fusor.

posts.cooked:
truher:

You can read our design doc 1

Looks like the design doc is private, I’m not able to access it

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
oh whoops, ok, fixed.

reading it again after a few months, it talks a lot about the protocol between the pose estimator node and the RoboRio: the complexity of so many node types is partly why we didn’t end up using any of it.  In 2027 we’ll just run this on the main controller.

posts.name: Matthew Milunic
posts.cooked:
I was doing some research on papers, and something that I found that seemed to be simple to implement but also sufficient at compensating for slipping is basically transforming a change in position for the wheel into a continuous movement/twist (logmap) relative to the wheel. Then you can just subtract the continuous movement the wheel should have moved at according to your odometry. Then you just have (continuous movement between poses) - (measured wheel movement) - (wheel slip) = error.

Basically you get one factor that takes in variables of robot_start, robot_end, and wheel_slip, and then parameters of wheel position relative to robot and wheel odometry measurement.

This error for most swerve wheels for this factor should only have variance in the direction of the wheel due to encoder variance and wheel diameter inconsistency. I use just a Gaussian for this noise model.

Then I have another factor that treats the wheel slip as a continuous movement (a twist2d equivalent) and give it a prior of [0,0,0]. The trick i used to make it estimate slip is then to make the noise model on this factor a Robust model. I went with the Welsch mEstimator one. This helps capture that once a wheel starts slipping it will usually have a very wrong velocity compared to its true ground velocity, whereas if it is not slipping it has a very narrow range of velocities it can take on, all very close to correct.

Now I just repeat that by making factors for all 4 wheels instead of just one.

TLDR: I treat the individual wheel slippage as a variable to solve for and use a robust noise model so it is resistant to outliers. Wheel slip = outliers.

So no real tire model, but it would be cool.

Edit: Tank and Mechanum can be implemented by reducing the number of swerve wheels to 2 and by changing the noise model for wheel slip to have an infinite variance in the direction the wheel can freely slide. All my wheel slip noise models have infinite variance for rotation as wheels typically turn with negligible resistance.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
@truher I’m looking at adding a variant of this factor for camera extrinsic calibration with tags at unknown poses. I want (world to tag origin, Pose3), (world to body, Pose2), and (body to camera, Pose3) unknown, with (camera calibration, Cal3) known.

It looks like as PlanarProjectionFactor is currently written, this would require that either the landmark pose be an Expression, or modifying PlanarProjectionFactor to deal with tag origin → tag corner transforms. Have yall thought about how we might approach implementing this?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: I think you’re describing exactly ProjectionFactorPPP except with Pose2 instead of Pose3 as the POSE parameter, so maybe it would just work if you added the wrap to gtsam_unstable.i?

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
truher:

ProjectionFactorPPP

Does that let me encode information about the 4 tag corners being exactly ±3in from tag N’s origin? It looks like the landmark position is a Pose3, so I can’t use an expression right?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Oh, I see now.  Each landmark is a Point3 representing a tag corner, so for fixed landmarks it’s ok to handle them independently, but not for mapping.   I’m not sure what the right approach would be.  You could use a factor per corner, and “between” factors linking to the tag center pose, but that would make the solver work pretty hard.  Maybe not that hard?  When I was working on this stuff last year, I used Python custom factors for prototyping, just to figure out what to do.  (Python custom factors are very slow!)  You could also ask Prof Dellaert on https://groups.google.com/g/gtsam-users , he’s very attentive and helpful.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
I asked on gtsam-users and got this response:

We have a bunch of factors, unit tests, example code on how to do that, in a project called “easyslam”, but it never made it into GTSAM. If you’re willing to do (or oversee) the work to PR it into GTSAM, probably in unstable/easyslam, I’d be happy to share the code. Let me know if interested – I can help by meeting with you about it.

the thing he mentions seems to be described here, from awhile ago:

https://repository.gatech.edu/server/api/core/bitstreams/3d97af7d-a98c-42e4-adc3-462b46ee0d60/content

wdyt?

posts.cooked:
Good find! I ftr have sent a join request to the google group which is still pending or I’d chime in there.

Looks like easyslam is exactly what we want. I wasn’t able to find the code for it linked in the paper or in github – were you?
